Use the tiny spoons to get several heaping spoonfuls of different granulated flavorings (such as garlic, ginger, cayenne, and yellow curry). Finally, you'll arrive at the sauces. Use a sampling spoon and try a sauce. If it's not that tasty, get another spoon and sample another sauce. Pick one or two that you like and ladle it into the small sauce bowl. I enjoy the 3G sauce, but you might not.  Finally, walk to the counter near the grill and present your bowl. They'll ask which starch you want. I picked udon noodle, but maybe you'll want rice or something. You can ask for 1 or more eggs to be added to your bowl here. They used to have eggs for you to grab in line, but I'm guessing too many of them dropped and broke. I believe you may be able to ask for a premade combination at the grill counter, but I wouldn't bother with that unless you're very lazy.  Grab a drink and maybe some condiments from the back area after you drop off your bowl to be cooked. They have those fancy Coca Cola machines that dispense seemingly hundreds of flavors from one spout. There's soy sauce, sriracha, and other things. Go back to your seat and wait an employee to present you with your bowl of cooked food. Eat and enjoy.  I will make this point again so that it's very clear. If you didn't add enough spices and whatnot, don't expect too many good things out of the bowl. You can probably still salvage it with the other condiments and some salt and pepper, and then you can berate yourself. It probably took me at least a couple of visits until I learned this lesson, and I'm so glad I did.  If you want a nice hot bowl of some Asian-inspired flavors with plenty of meat and some carbs, this is a good option. You know what flavors you're getting because you're designing the recipe, and that sure bet is probably worth $12 or so on a regular basis for some people.

This place has an interesting concept but, from entering the restaurant to being seated to prepping food and waiting for it to be cooked seems like a lot of wasted time and money. First they should have you start at the line to order food then seat yourself after food order is in. Also based on my experience and working F&B operations for over a decade in fine dining you should not allow guest mess with raw food in this way based on cross contamination. They should have a couple of people based on a chipotle ordering line to put your food together. This would eliminate any type of cross contamination. Also this would look more professional as well put my mind at ease for health and safety purposes. They could then hand off food for chef to cook. Eliminate the person from seating guest because this made no sense. This company is obviously not local and they thought sense they are opening a location in Las Vegas makes so much sense to put in a bar. Well surprise a bar makes no sense in a place like this. You can offer beer and wine(sake) and probably make the same if not do better since you are devoted to having the ridiculous bar area. This place needs an overhaul and you need people in there who actually know the business of restaurants rather than some high schoolers who think they know how to run Food and Beverage. They will never be successful if this place isn't executed correctly. Also prices need to be adjusted meaning reduce by a dollar in everything including 2.79 for a soda give me a break you took the Chipotle model and are charging at a premium something that isn't even near the quality of chipotle. If you are going to rip off an idea than it needs to executed correctly. Do not think you can change the genre of food and do it the same way and think you can be more successful. Good luck I would think about trying this place if they would consider making some of these changes.

So let me start off by saying the the food is incredible and it's so cool to be able to season restaurant food to your liking. The options and ability to combine various meats are crazy cool. This is truly Mongolian barbecue. The only downside is ToGo takes forever because you must wait behind the guests dining in. So if there are 10-15 guests, expect an hour wait. It's impossible to call ahead because even if you know what you want, how do you convey portions? So long story short, if you're going to go- eat there and don't be pressed for time when you go. I recommend the Sriracha chicken and the Udon noodles.

Food was fine but the cost went up since the last time we have been here. That's fine too. What's not fine is throwing money back at my mother with a short aggressive "you're short" and walking away rather than waiting a half second for the $3 we were short.  We will definitely not be going back. Not if throwing someone's money in their face is acceptable.
No longer all you can eat for a prefix price bad health inspections in the past. Won't be back.
Excellent value for the money. Fairly inexpensive, good quality food. $1 beers on Sunday is a plus.

Delicious!  Pick your bowl size (small, regular, large) and then pack it with steak, chicken, fish, tofu. Move on to the fresh veggies, add some spices, and finally choose your sauce. The chef whips it all together and your delicious bowl is ready in a few short minutes.
The food is tasty, and the service friendly. It's a bit pricey, though. I would return.

Really tasty, but expect to wait at least half an hour to get each bowl. I've been to a similar business out in Arizona and it was only 8$ for unlimited bowls instead of 15$....so it's a bit pricey for what it is. Dining room is also a claustrophobic little maze that's hard to navigate. The bowls that you get to select your ingredients are way tinier than they should be for 10$ and 3$ for a tiny bowl of edamame is laughable. Great potential, good flavor, but too high of price and too slow of service to be really excellent.
Took us late in the night and gave us great service ! Love the food ! Great place ! Been here many times!
Excellent service and food! My server Jessica was very helpful, knowledgable and caring, the grill masters were on point with the cooking, and the place was clean... just a very enjoyable experience!

So I had never been to a place like this, although I have seen them in other malls. Here, you are seated and then your server explains to you how it works (and very, VERY quickly, I might add... I know the concept is simple but I needed to know why the menu didn't exactly describe the food... and since I've written this review AFTER I've eaten here, I still don't know why the damn menu can't help out with explanations of some of the sauces and spices).   You are handed a small silver bowl (kinda like a doggy dish... huh.) You walk your lazy ass over to the line and load up on your choice of however much you want of raw chicken, beef, pork, shrimp, scallops, "krab" and whatever else is on this chilled salad bar. Playing upchuck-roulette isn't one of my favorite ways to spend an evening but hey, I'll try anything once.  From here you move on to a stack of different spices (which range from mild to ass-ripping) and while they are labeled, if you don't know what something is to begin with, then you just don't know. I picked three (one was garlic powder and the other two I couldn't tell you) and sprinkled my shrimp/chicken/beef. On to the vegetables! Here we have what amounts to a salad bar with a few Asian twists. I sometimes think of myself in the same way when I'm gettin' down, and that's only when my ego is in full force. But I digress. You load up veggies into your bowl, such as broccoli, spinach, baby corn, water chestnuts, mushrooms... and I threw in a few of those kung pao hot peppers, just for fun. Then you move down the line to the sauces! Here's where it gets stupid: There are about 20 different sauces. There are even tasting spoons if you don't know what something is. But my problem with this is that I'm not going to stand here and taste a bunch of stuff and hold up the line (although I am sure plenty of nimrods do). So I just closed my eyes and picked three, just like with the spices. Small scoops into a little dipping container and then you move down to the cook, who will fire up your food with noodles or rice and then have it brought directly to your table.  I can't tell you what I picked as far as sauces and seasonings go, but the food was cooked perfectly. Beef wasn't chewy and there was a nice sear on the sides of all of the meats. At first, I was disappointed because I couldnt taste any of my flavorings. But then a few minutes went by and I got that steamy, face-reddening, eye-watering aftertaste heat that only Asian food can produce. Great success! And I didn't get salmonella, either! (this time.) Oh... AAAND.... **$1 happy hour well drinks with a decent-to-heavy pour.**

I travel every week. This is some of the worst I have eaten in an airport in the last 10 years. Had the Mongolia Bowl, their signature dish. The meat was enzymatically tenderized mush. They only gave you 2 oz of meat anyways. The rest was limp bell peppers and canned pineapple tid-bits. The sauce was sweet and cloying. The "fried rice" was instant rice mixed with soy sauce. If in CLT, keep moving.

Really, really good! We first walked in, and just stood there for a long time. Almost left, but they had just opened and we gave them time. Once we were seated, we met Mia. It was our first time there. We chose to make our own bowl. She walked us over, explained how it worked and let us loose on deciding what wonderful, fresh meat, veggies and sauces we wanted.   They have cards that offer suggestions on what to choose, or you can choose whatever sounds good. Get more veggies than you think...smashing it down in the bowl as you go along...as they cook down. I loved the idea of grabbing an egg so there would be scrambled egg in the mix, so don't forget to grab the egg along the way if that's what you like. Yum!  Really liked the experience. Mia checked back with us, as did the manager. Really loved the food! The service was great. We were really glad we didn't listen to the random bad reviews. This place is great.

My coworkers rave about this spot so I gave them a try. I am so happy I did! The food was delicious and the choices are endless! My only complaint was that I ordered my dish with noodles and they used rice as well. I don't know if they put rice in every bowl but it included some onions which I really hate. Outside of that, the servers are attentive and the foods fabulous!
This location is now closed. Unfortunate. Really enjoyed. Closest is now at Tempe Marketpkace

LOVE this place!!! When you go in there are 3 different bowl sizes and you can pile this bowl with a variety of different meats, vegetables, spices, and sauces.  It is very filling once it's stir-fryed and served to you. There should be another location opened because there is only one location so far.

I've reviewed the location at Arrowhead after a no so pleasant experience there. Was in the Paradise Valley area the thought I'd give this location a shot because I was really craving some stir fry. The food, just still ok. Not worth $9.99 per bowl. I do like the selection of protein and veggies. The service was just ok too. I checked in on Yelp to redeem 10% off, showed my server who still forgot to take it off my bill. He did fix it immediately. Also, when we first sat I reviewed the table menu briefly for a drink. While I did that he proceeded to tell me of about 3 or 4 items in the menu (appetizers, dessert, etc) that were no longer available.  Probably a good idea for management to get updated menus (JMO).  My issue is still the price though. I have to be really hungry and not willing to drive elsewhere to spend that kind of moola for just a single bowl of just okay mongolian.

Went for lunch here today.  It was only my second time.  The first time was okay so I thought I'd give it another try with my little boy.  Staff was friendly as was with my first visit.  Seated right away.  When we received our food we both immediately started enjoying.  Well after a few bites I noticed that a bite I was getting ready to put in my mouth had 1/2 bright blue rubberband in it.  I pulled it out and set it on the edge of my bowl then immediately noticed the next bite had a hair in it.  I initially thought it was maybe me just seeing things.  The manager walked over to see how I was doing.  I shared with him that I pulled the blue rubberband from bowl and found what appears to be hair still in my bowl.  He apolgized said the rubberband wasnt even something they use and the hair might just be bamboo sting.  At that point I didn't take his apology as sincere.  Well not like he could tell for sure I wasn't taking any chances so I stopped eating after that.  I hadnt barely made a dent in my bowl.  He stated he would "take some off my bill".  I would have honestly rather been offered a choice to go make a new bowl or discounted bill because I basically left hungry.  The "discount" on my bill before tax was almost $18 then a $2.80 discount then tax added back on total back up to about $18.  Like I said I didn't eat much of my bowl so I still paid the full price for it and had what amounted to the tax comped on my bill.    My waitress was really nice about but I know she had no say in what action the manager would take.  Feedback to Management: Next time better practice would be to offer customer to make new bowl (which would have been my choice), gift card for next visit, or just remove the whole tanted bowl from the bill.  A small discount is nothing considering I could have had a rubberband in my digestive system.  Highly likely I won't be back.  Other better stir fry joints I can give my business to.

We were excited to come to this Mongolian grill suggested by family.  First of all, we visited on a Friday night. This location is in the Tempe Marketplace, an outdoor mall. Parking was horrible, and that is not the fault of the restaurant.  The restaurant wasn't too busy, and the hostess quickly seated our group. Something had apparently spilled on the floor near the bar long before we arrived and we all walked through it. The service and customers had spread whatever was spilled in a sticky mess all throughout the restaurant. Gross.  To top that, the first table we sat at was also sticky, and before the waitress came back, we had found ourselves a new table.  There is quite a selection of meats and veggies, this was a plus. However, the selection of sauces, while extensive, is completely (almost?) sugar-based. It would be nice to have had some options that were lower calorie or lower glycemic index. Even just oil and soy sauce would have been nice.  The service came around often, however she never checked to see what everyone needed before darted off to get one person's drink., which resulted in her needing to make many more trips.  Overall the food was really just so-so, and the fresh meat that others describe was actually frozen when we made our bowls.

Genghis is the bomb! If you like YC's Mongolian, you will LOVE Genghis. They use fresh meat, not that packaged frozen crap. In itself it's such a different experience, and a fresh idea for a restaurant.  The bar is pretty fresh too, if you enjoy awesome happy hour prices.

Superb customer service here, 5 stars for sure. We came for dinner around 540 and there was plenty of seating. The hostess showed us our table and explained how things worked, and a gentleman came to take our drink orders. Think he was the manager, he checked up on us multiple times as well as everyone else in the place.  We took our cards with us and got in line. It got busy as everyone else seemed to join us at the same time. We chose our bowl size and got a tray and two small cups for our sauces. You move down the line and add protein, spices, veggies and other toppings. The guy in front of us was clearly a pro as he was stuffing his bowl and pushing down the contents like there was no tomorrow. But he took forever so that was annoying and I bypassed him. Love that they had several seafood options as well as tofu to suit my pescatarian diet. At the end, one of the cooks takes our card and asks if we'd like noodles and/or rice and how many eggs (2 for a regular bowl). I asked for both noodles and rice but only got noodles, so that was a small bummer but the noodles were good.   Overall I put way too much sauce and white fish but it was surely a filling meal. Next time I'll have to follow the guidelines for specific sauces cuz I was just adding everything that sounded good. It ended up being on the sweet side but the manager came through with some Sriracha sauce.

I eat here all the time and it always seems like something's changed when I go lol. I have a fail safe for a delicious bowl. They no longer have the sauce available that was my favorite. The small, med, large bowl option change is something I do not like because now I have to spend more to get what I was getting before. They do have a great happy hour and nice staff. I do enjoy this over YCs because the food is FRESH. Once it is cooked it makes a difference joy being cooked from a frozen state. Also they have more options for protein.
Decent food that is reasonably priced.  5 stars because this place is a good value for the cost.  I prefer for lunch.

I'm giving this place a 3 out of five because I loved the food,but the service was lacking. This was my first time eating here and I felt that my server did not properly explain everything. She did not mention the booklets they had with recipes you could make, did not tell us there were bowls in the menu that we could order, and did not really explain the process.   I did not like the fact that you have to scoop the meat yourself because its disgusting. Touching a cold, wet, meat juice infested tong is gross. They should come up with some other way of handling the meat. I felt like they did offer a variety of meats, veggies, fruits and sauces.   The food came back really fast and it was very tasty.
Pretty good for airport food. Huge portions. Had the spicy shrimp chow mein.. it was awesome. needed a little more spice, added one of their hot sauce packets.. did the trick..
Love it great price! Load your bowl up with meat and the veggies come last.  I got the medium bowl and I could not finish

This was my first time eating here and I found it to be a very pleasant experience. Our waiter was very friendly and helpful. He explained how the process all worked and was very on top of refilling our drinks. My kids really enjoyed being able to make their own bowls and had a lot of fun with it. The meats are fresh and not frozen, there's plenty to choose from as far as topping are concerned. You can sample the sauces to find the one you like the best or you can mix and match. Bottom line was that the food was good, the prices were fair, and the customer service was great. Will be coming back!

It was me and my boyfriends first time eating here and our first impressions were awful. The exterior is really washed out and ugly and then when we go inside we get sat at a dirty table. We had no idea what we were doing and the waitress explained it a bit to us but the guy behind the counter was AWFUL.(he was the guy with the snake bites, dressed like he was still in highschool) He didn't help us at all besides giving us our bowls. He just sat there talking to a girl the whole time. I had no idea was the small container was for, I thought it was for the spices. It was a lot simpler than what it felt like at the time. I just wanted to leave without ordering anything because of how overwhelming it was. Just thinking about the unsupervised raw meat section makes my stomach hurt. The whole place just seemed very unsanitary and the employees seemed lazy. When we finally got our bowls, my boyfriends was half full. The prices are horrendous and the customers do half the work. We decided not to say anything and just never come back. The waitress was great and made our experience slightly better.

This location was better a year ago before they turned it around to make it like all the other ones. I remember back in the day, Happy Hour was all weekend and all well drinks were $2!!  They didn't have all the perks, like the appetizers or "large" bowl option, or even the little ordering cards.  I keep going back though, and the food is still tasting good, so I am acclimating. I really like the build-it-yourself philosophy.  Perhaps I am a control freak, but I like to decide how much spice and sauce and broccoli goes into my bowl. I like a lot of broccoli, moderate amount of sauce, and a little spice.  My husband goes the complete opposite route with no broccoli, tons of sauce, and too much spice. It just would not be a complete experience at Genghis Grill if it does not include him pondering that maybe his bowl is too spicy.  Getting back to those appetizers, I suggest skipping them. If you shove down all the contents of your bowl as you  go through the line, a regular bowl is enough food.  We got the edamame last time because it was included in a coupon, and it was mediocre. We also got the ice cream since it was also included in the coupon, and it was also mediocre.  Envision two very small scoops of vanilla ice cream in a small dish, lightly drizzled with chocolate sauce.  That is the sundae. No whip cream, no sprinkles and no cherry on top.   The servers are always friendly and the people watching is usually acceptably entertaining.  Sign up for their mailing list because you get good coupons (although then you wind up with boring edamame and cherry-less sundaes....). Kids eat free on Tuesdays!

This place is great ! Fresh ingredients , you make your way , I like that a drink is included in the price of your bowl. Friendly service . The outcome of your work is delicious ! Very filling ! We will for sure make this a regular place to visit ! And they serve booze :)

For a "semi-fast-food" reataurant, Genghis Grill is pretty darn good. For those who have never been, its a mongolian bowl buffet style place, similar to YC. Yoi stack up a bowl full of meats and veggies and rice/noodles and they grill it for you on a giant grill. Plus they have recently added menu dishes such as Asian tacos, chicken skewers and salads, which I think was a great move. Plus they havr super cheap Happy Hour beer and sake bombs!

This is a choose your own adventure kind of restaurant.  How your food ends up tasting is mostly up to you.  They let you pile up your bowl as high as you want, so go ahead and mash some food down when you're stuffing it.  I was quite impressed with the amount of meats they had.  Chicken, pork, shrimp, beef, ham, turkey.  Big good sized shrimp too by the way.  I can't even remember all the meats.  Most stir-fry places have 3 or 4 meats, this place probably has close to 10.  The next station is seasoning.  There's about 12 options here as well.  I stuck with the cajun spices for the night.  Remember that just a couple of dashes is all you need.  Plenty of vegetables.  Tons of vegetables.  Mini corn, broccali, green beans, spinach, cabbage, pineapple, celery, mushrooms.  Tons of stuff.  Then the sauces.  I was recommended the Szechuan sauce by a friend and it was good.  I don't know what it is exactly....it's like a thin teriyaki sauce? No, that's not right.  I can't describe it.  In any case, it was good.  There was about 10 other sauces: "stir-fry" sauce, sweet and sour, teriyaki and more.  Unfortunately for someone who is watching their carbs, every single sauce is thickened up with wheat.  The last station is the "starches" which includes a few kinds of rice and a few kinds of noodles.  Tortillas was also an option.  I'm avoiding carbs where I can so I skipped out on this last option.  What really made me happy is that nobody made a big deal or cared about me skipping out on "filler" when I was doing the all-you-can-eat option.  With a soda and the all you can eat option, my total for one person before tip was $17.  It's not terribly expensive, but I'm not exactly impressed with the cost.

Genghis grill is the best. I haven't ate here for year, but nothing ever changed. Rather than making a premade recipe, I decided to make my own. Be careful on the seasoning though! A lot of seasoning can tramendously affect the taste. I was a little bit frightened as to see what it is like and tasted. The chef's did not disappoint. I liked it (I got rice noodles). The rice noodles to be honest was a bittle bland, but I got a side of teriyaki sauce and it made the rice noodles more tasty.  The service was decent. The waitress was a little slow but in the end acconplished what we requested.  The atmosphere was clean and welcoming...a little bit dark for lunch time.

This is an Americanized-Imitation of Mongolian BBQ. The taste is okay......There are way to many options out on the floor that aren't favorable. The self serving area always feels so dirty and unorganized. It's always either spilled over or raw food is on the surfaces. The tongs are crossed between raw meats. I do not care for the sauce station as there should be recipes blatant so you may either have a traditional Mongolian taste or make what you like , at this point just know it's way too confusing and it's not worth going. You have keep finding someone because there is no one tending the self serve stations.

We loved the greeting and our server. She explained the process extremely well. Yet, when it's busy and people ahead and behind you, it's a bit overwhelming. It all turned out fine and delicious. We will be back!!

Just came to Ghengis Grill with w family members..My brother was running low on money so he wasn't going to order anything..The owner walked to our table and let us know that they were closing early and that everyone's tab was covered and to enjoy ourselves.   My response was "are you serious??" His response "Yeah...it's Christmas"  What a blessing!

This was our second time here and we loved it again. I'm not a great cook so I was admittedly a bit intimidated by having to add my own spices, but it worked out well and both my husband and I enjoyed what we made. The food tastes fresh and flavorful and the staff here is very friendly and accommodating, especially the manager Bill. Highly recommend.

MIKE AND JESS are the BEST bartenders always with great service. Come here at the bar area and they are the greatest and joyest to be around. BEER PRICE AMAZING. ASK JUST ASK AND SAVE. food is also AMAZING.

I guess the concept is cool but unless you know what your doing the food usually comes out just OK. I've been here 4 times and not once had I been blown away with what I created (even when I follow the recipe). P.s. Don't order their potstickers

I regularly visit here for lunch or dinner but tonight's visit was brief yet exceptional. Our server was John and he was very thorough, professional, and knowledgeable. We will be returning again and again and would absolutely recommend this place to anyone and everyone! Also, the food is always fantastic.
I love this place! Have been here 4 times now and plan to keep coming. Service is great, especially our server ALYSSA. She was such a sweetheart and made sure we had a great experience!
Very generous portions, great taste and service is always great. My husband and I come here as often as we can, we love this place.

I've been eating here with a friend for a few years for lunch, a kind of tradition to do before or after seeing a movie at the local theater next door in this trendy outdoor mall. I like putting together my own meal with the meat, veggies and starch I like. The food is well prepared and quite tasty. I looked at the reviews and have had much better luck with the service; it's been very good for us, never a problem.   There have been a few recent changes. There are now three bowl sizes to choose from, and the effect is that to get the same size as before, it costs a few dollars more. While the place is a good lunchtime restaurant, it is a just a bit pricey now for this location. Also, there's a computer tablet at the table. The servers are helpful in showing how to navigate this, although I'm not that high tech so don't really feel the need for this.   Overall, I like the place and will continue to go there when in the area to meet a friend for a movie. I find it better than the other restaurants at this mall location.

If I could give them 0 stars I would. The service was terrible from the start. The hostess set us at a very tall table when we had a 7 month old with us. Thanks for the help. When I checked out the where to pick up the bowls, the meat looks slimy and not well kept. When my husband went over there they asked him for some card that we were never given.   We left feeling like we were the problem. We didn't order! They seem to be stuck in social media world and not a real human job.   Terrible!!!

We frequent this location often on Tuesdays because kids eat free which is wonderful. They also have $1 domestic beers which we appreciate with our meal choices. The food is always abundant and clean. The wait staff is the only downfall of this location and the tables and booths are not always clean which is such a turn off. We will keep going back for the food not the atmosphere.

A caveat to this review is that I love to cook and make my own meal. Guess what; this is the place for control freaks like me. The fresh diversity of meats, chicken and fish; are outstanding! The veggies are very fresh as well. I recommend that you try the sauces first with the little spoons. Here you are master of your own pallet. You can ask them to use less or no oil to make the meal a little healthier. Choose wisely because the portions are as generous as you want to make of them! The owner is awesome and the cast and crew are ubber friendly. There happy hour specials are excellent if your a well drinker. I recommend making yourself a spicy Mongo beef. Use the N.Y strip instead of the sliced beef and you will know where I am coming from!

It's the whitest Mongolian Barbecue EVER. And not in a good way. What kind of Mongolian place serves tortillas and pepperoni?! No thank you.  The only reason it doesn't get one star is that it didn't taste horribile.

Loved this place their first year.  I keep going back hoping for what we loved at first but it's just not there.  No more shrimp or shelled edamame to add to your bowl.  Prices are ridiculous for less than what they used to give.  The only reason to go these days is the cool Coke machine.  It's right next to the Sunset Station who has a better mongolian grill and you get the whole buffet for less than what these guys charge.  Wish you'd stayed as good as when you opened.

Holy crap, out of all restaurant I picked this place.   Food: the Mongolian rice was hard and the veges was not cooked at all. Orange chicken was so nasty, it should be called bell pepper chicken not orange.   Serivce: let's say the girl was not very responsive.  But I do give 2 stars for the manager being so polite and letting us know how everything worked.   Overall I probably would not be returning.

Self serve Mongolian Grill in the Las Vegas suburbs.  You get a choice of three different sizes of bowls to start. You bring your bowl to the selection bar. You start by filling your bar with your choice of meat and/or seafood. You then add vegetables, fruit, and spices. You then bring your bowl to the grill area. You can tell the chef to add up to two grains like rice or noodles. The chef takes your bowl and cooks its contents.  The waitress will bring your bowl to your table when it is ready.  I was pleasantly surprised by the taste and process. The waitstaff was friendly.

I'm a super fan on this place! Anytime I'm in control of amount and portion size I'm going to be a happy camper! This is a great place to go when you can't decided on what to eat! With it being build your own stir fry everyone's happy because they can customize!

When you walk into Genghis grill, they ask if you've ever been there before while they assemble steel bowls.  Yes, of course I have, I answer as I'm led to a table and I order drinks. Then I take my battered little bucket (you feel like a Unicef kid for a minute) and head to the assembly area, and here is where Genghis Grill outshines their competition.  The quality of the meats, seafood and vegetable is clearly a cut above almost every other Mongolian Grill type establishment.  Since I don't eat meat I put some shrimp and scallops in the bowl, and assemble my favorite mix.  I do not recommend cramming too much meat into your bowl -- a juvenile mistake I see made by kids with bad skin and future cardiac issues.   Take it easy on the sauces since they are laden with sodium and oil.  You will be pleasantly surprised at the volume of food that your bowl + rice/noodle mix will create.   Friendly staff and a decent selection of beers.  As others have noted, it can take time to get your check and get out the door.  In noting some other reviews I think I think it would be helpful for Genghis Grill to really emphasize that overdoing the sauces will just destroy your meal.

As always, a bowl full of different foods all comes to the table perfectly cooked.   The manager Tommy was super helpful dealing with a a difficult food allergy at the table.   We used to come here all the time when we lived a block away. We will now be driving across the city to be regulars.

I love genghis grill. I wish they had all you can eat so I can give it 5 stars. This place is better than stir krazy which I don't understand how that place got a higher review rating than genghis grill. They have a lot of options and their price is decent. It's a little cheaper for lunch time. I go here often for Mongolian BBQ

Mmmm mmmm good!  I love me some Mongolian food!  Went with a friend on a Sunday around 5:00 and there really wasn't a wait at all which was great since we were hungry!  The host was very friendly as was our server who greeted us right away to take our drink orders.  As soon as that was done we made our way to the fresh ingredient area.  I was pleasantly surprised to see what I would consider an above average selection of various meats and vegetables available.  Marinated steak anyone?  Pineapple?  I think I will!  I also loved that you can pick from different options to go along with your food (steamed rice, fried rice, noodles, tortillas, and a couple others I can't remember).  I chose the fried rice and I'm proud to admit that I ate the whole bowl, it was delicious!  Next time I'm up this way I'll definitely be making a pit stop here!

I've been to a few different Genghis Grills and I have to say this location has been the best one so far thanks to their staff.  Everyone I came into contact with was friendly from the hostess to the guy stocking the veggies to the cook to my actual waiter.  They all said hello and made conversation as I went about everything which was nice.  My waiter almost verged on being TOO attentive which I know sounds crazy but in the 20-25 minutes I was there he came over to check on me 6 times and that's no exaggeration.  Not to mention he seemed to keep cleaning the same table and re-arranging the same chairs nearby my table multiple times.  He was nice though and it's better to have a server who's too attentive rather than one you can't seem to get to come to your table.  My only gripe with all the Genghis Grills has got to be the ingredient station.  Everything tastes wonderful when it's cooked but it just seems like no matter what time of day I go in, the ingredients look like they're last nights leftovers.  Just not very fresh looking.  I'm sure it's hard to keep them looking fresh as they're sitting out exposed but couldn't you just switch them out a little more frequently?

As a self-described Genghis Grill junky this one left me feeling less than high.  Stopped in to grab some takeout so that I could rent Safe Haven and watch it at home with the bestie (great movie btw) on a Wednesday night around 8:30.  It wasn't busy so the hostess greeted us right away and told us the procedure for takeout, load up the bowls, pay at the bar and they'll bring us the food.  We made our way through the ingredient stations and got up to the area where you tell them what kind of starches you want.  I asked for brown rice and then waited for my friend to finish with her ingredients.  She got the Udon noodles which then caused the guy cooking everything to come back to me and start asking if I was sure I wanted brown rice, because I could get noodles instead!  He concluded with asking if I was trying to be healthy.  Uhhhh, maybe I am or maybe I'm not, regardless just give me the food I ask for without an argument!!!  After that we headed to the bar to wait and pay.  However none of the 3-4 servers/bartenders/anyone stopped to find out what we needed until we'd been sitting there for a while.  Finally the one girl who actually looked like she was busy came over to help us and get our checks for us.  It was just not the level of quality I expect from Genghis and I was a bit disappointed.

Great food at a great price.  The happy hour is fantastic and the quality of the meat, veggies and the overall food is fabulous.  This is much better than the other Mongolian BBQ places around Phoenix and Scottsdale.  VERY clean.  The beef was fresh and of high quality.. not stringy.  The chicken is also fresh and the marinated lime chicken is awesome.  The fresh vegitables and the sauces are what make the place a great option!

Agree with a review below about changing to different bowl sizes and what not does seem like they're trying to nickel and dime you. You make your own bowl so if you don't like it,  it is your fault. Never had a bad time, try a fishbowl great drink for two. Though new electronic check out is annoying. Takes up to much room on table when with four people, and the servers dont have much to do with it being a self service.

I love Genghis Grill. We went most recently because I had a birthday coupon from them for a free bowl, but I've been there several times before and each time this place has been consistently tasty. I like building my own meal from their provided options, and somehow I always manage to make mine pretty darn good. I do think it is a little expensive, but then again you can go ahead and pile up the meat and veggies in your bowl if you want to get the most food for your money.   The only downside is that the place is pretty crowded (tables and benches are placed close together) and often pretty loud. They haven't been as busy the past few times I've been there, but I think that's because it's summer and the ASU kids have cleared out.  This is our usual stop when we are at the Tempe Marketplace. It's hard to resist.

First off, I read all the negative reviews about the food not tasting good, too little sauce, the food sits outs.  YOU PEOPLE ARE INSANE!!!!1 1. if you don't like your bowl, pick different things to put in your bowl, if its not enough sauce ask for more sauce, and you don't like that the meat sits out??? even though its over ice (which is tested to make sure its at proper temperature) then ask for the meat in the walk in.   all the complaints are retarded cause YOU MAKE YOUR OWN BOWL WITH THE FREEDOM TO DO WHATEVER YOU WANT!!! 'merica  On a serious note, I personally love love love ghengis grill. I have yet to have a bad server, I love the food and have never had an issue. the manager always comes over to make sure the food tastes good. (hello people if it doesn't, tell them. they will get you something new). It is a little pricey but when your stacking the bowl so high you bring home enough leftovers for a whole new meal then I cant complain.  Ghengis is one of my favorite spots for sure.

You build you're own bowl so if it tastes horrible you're to blame. The variety of ingredients is pretty decent but overall there really isn't anything special about this place. The quality is pretty average and their limited menu for appetizers is a little disappointing.   Good if you really need a quick bite and don't want to give into the temptation of fast food.

Not your typical Mongolian Grill, this place is great, why? Because you make the menu! They have a wide array of items to put in your bowl. Well that sounds quite typical of a Mongolian Grill! I heard someone say. Ok so here is the not typical part: They have things not normally found at a Mongolian Grill such as Pepperoni! I should also mention the incredible selection of sauces. They also have a great loyalty club! Live it up, you are in Las Vegas for cryin' out loud!
Great selection of meats, vegtables, sauces and seasonings.  Fun for the whole family!

Came here with friends for some asian food.   It was a bit confusing at first since the waitresses don't really tell you how the process works. There aren't any signs either, especially when it comes to pricing. To this day, I'm not really sure how much my regular bowl was since my friend paid for my meal. Although, I'm surprised there were many options to put in your bowl compared to your typical Mongolian style restaurant.   I would probably not come back to this place.
The food is just okay.  I think having servers, a hostess, and a bar is an excuse to charge more.  YC's is a simpler set-up, it's cheaper, and you get more food.  Enough said.

I'm so excited that Charlotte finally has a Mongolian barbecue. And I'm doubly excited that it's just up the road from my office. Yeah for Genghis Grill for getting SO much right out of the gate. First of all, they have done an excellent job hiring enthusiastic servers who seem to genuinely enjoy their jobs. Second, they have the whole food allergy thing completely under control -- even gluten-free! Third, they have a full bar, so while your kids chow down on 2 or 3 bowls of noodles and such, you can actually have a cocktail or beer and enjoy the experience.   Lunch or dinner, I think this place is a slam dunk, if you want an easy dining experience that is sure to please everyone in your group.

My wife enjoyed her meal, but I'm pretty picky when I experience the same style of food that I've had before, YC's in particular. After being seated, we grabbed our bowls and headed towards the food line. There were three rows of food and condiments. The third row was a little difficult to get to. None of the employees were paying attention to the food. You could see where people had gotten something and it spilled onto the edge of another container of food. The setup was totally inefficient. The selections were so-so. I was surprised that we could only order our noodles or rice at the end. For noodles, they used soba noodles which are a lot thicker than YC's and THEY control the portion. WHERE's THE NOODLES!! And that is one reason out of several, why I won't be back.

AWESOME place to eat. With the kids also. Lunch and dinner are great! Dined here multiple times and never waited to get a seat. Staff is super friendly and helpful explaining the process in case you've never been there. Also, the kids loved how they make the giant flames over the flattop grill at dinner time!

I really enjoy this spot. It's close to home and the food is good. The staff has always been welcoming and helpful.   How does it work? The hostess will seat you and then a server stops by to give you a card that you'll take through the line. The first thing you'll choose in the line is the size of the bowl. I always choose the smallest because you'll add stuff at the end that will make the portion larger than it seems. The first section of food is all meat and seafood. Next up is vegetables and seasonings. The final section contains a variety of sauces. Lastly, you'll take it to the grill area where you can add options like eggs, fried rice, udon noodles, or pasta to name a few. While you wait you grab your drink and head back to the table to wait for the server to bring your food.  What do I love about it? You can create a variety of flavors and themes when choosing your meal. The meats, sauces, seasonings, and vegetables can be changed up on every visit to create completely different meals. One visit could be sweet-n-sour chicken and another visit could be a seafood dish with curry seasoning. The bowls come up pretty quickly so it's a nice cross between fast food and full service dining. The cost of the bowl is reasonable for the amount of food and a low cost option for a quick lunch or dinner. They also have a reward card to get a bowl free after 10 purchases.

As these types of places go it was well below average.  A.better choice would be YC's at Indian Bend near the 101.  This place was not big on being clean and tidy.  Ingredients were not fresh looking on bar.  Presented a bowl that host had his fingers in.  Asked for another and was accommodated but he looked stunned.  All in all a mediocre experience.

I finally found an opportunity to visit this place and I was pleasantly surprised.  This is still the new kid on the block in this area, and as this was our first time, we were not alone with the new dining experience.  You hear people mention that you do all but cook the food, this is true, but let me add one thing......if you choose a variety of sauces, this will end up as one sauce.  This is a bowl of food that you choose from a raw and uncooked state.  You place it into a small stainless dish that is kept at the hostess stand that she wipes out with a towel, and is handed to you as you enter.  After working in restaurants for a very long time, I am never comfortable placing raw chicken and shaved meat together in one bowl, especially with veggies.  This is like a lazy mans "Japanese Restaurant" where you sit at individual tables instead of around the grill master.  It was interesting, but for the small bowl ($9.99) it just did not seem to be a great value.  The staff was friendly, the location was clean, but I am sure that even though the food gets cooked, raw chicken, raw meat, and seafood, do not need to reside in a bowl with uncooked veggies.  May visit again, using just one meat, and one sauce.  NCFoodGuy

Well this place is really neat. The only way you wont like your food is if you screw it up. i recommend that for your first time you get the endless bowl and dont pile the stuff on when you go through the line. That way if you really hate it you can start over! There are recipe cards at the beginning of the line, which we did not use. You will choose your proteins first. a great variety of beef, chicken, pork, sausage, shrimp, calamari, scallops etc. next choose your spices, a little goes a long way and remember that you have the choice of sauces at the end of the line too. the dragon salt I am told is very spicy next choose your vegetables a great selection of raw vegetables and some fruits even pico de galo, there is whole eggs there too if you like that in your stir fry.  at the end you can choose your sauce, leave it off all together or have them cook it in or maybe take it to your table to add yourself. there are small spoons to taste the different sauces, but please be courtious to the patrons behind you throughout the line and donw linger in one area to long.  next approach the cooking station and tell them what starch you would like, I myself loved the noodles in mine, my husband gets the fried rice.  take your number card to your table and place it in the stand that is on your table, if you have several cards fan them out so the servers can see it and bring you the bowl when finished cooking.   my husband has a rewards card and if you live near here is it well worth it! you can get free bowls really quickly! this is a fun expereince for children since it is almost like they are making there own meal, in a sense they are except for the actual cooking!  We will go again!

This was a fun place to eat,  you can build your own bowl (like a typical mongolian restaurant) and they have an unlimited option for $4 more which is great for trying different creations.  One thing i really liked was the "starch"  options. They offer noodles and rice,  but also offer things like tortillas which adds a whole new element. Very reasonably priced.

I love options, which Genghis has plenty of. I'm still perfecting my bowl of noodles (udon, of course), but I'm getting there through much experimentation. Every time we come here, we somehow seem to always get the same waiter, which is great because he's so attentive. Plus, he suggested a side of sour cream and cheese to accompany my tortillas--good call. Anyway, the food stations are always well cleaned and well stocked during the days I've been. The chefs at the grill have smiled and greeted me. My steak is not overcooked and my veggies still have the right amount of crunch.   I like coming by for happy hour, when they have three kinds of house wines that are $4/glass. The same wines are available for their Wednesday deal for two bowls and a bottle for $25, which made our date night last week. And this location will sometimes give away free bowls if you say a certain phrase that they post on their Facebook page, so keep a look out!

The first thing that stood out as soon as I entered this establishment was the fact that it was empty. The waitress came to our table and immediately hounded us with questions. We weren't even sitting yet! She also brought along 9 bowls with her in 3 varying sizes. She wasn't wearing any gloves, and the bowls were not on any trays. She asked us for our name and bowl size and then handed each of us a card and a bowl. I have been to two different Genghis in AZ so I found this particular practice odd and off putting. I am used to going to the food area and being handed there a bowl on a tray from someone wearing gloves. Also keep in mind that she brought 9 bowls and there were only 3 of us.. I can only assume that those remaining 6 bowls would be carried back to where ever she got them and used later because I certainly can't see them throwing those 6 bowls in the wash. Especially if this is the normal practice each time a customer comes in.. That would be a lot of unused bowls to be washed. So imagine how many times those unused bowls go back and forth between tables and how many times the waitress has to touch them (without gloves) and how many different waitresses end up touching the same bowl. Very unsanitary! This little practice alone caused us to leave and I am so glad I did. On the way out I noticed that they had a C grade! When there is raw meat sitting out, a C grade is very scary.
I come here pretty regularly. It's good food and it's pretty fun creating your own delicacy. I wouldn't recommend putting bacon in your bowl. I put a little piece and it made my bowl too greasy.

I've been to a few different locations and they have all been consistently great. Clean restaurant, the service is good, and plenty of food.   This style of making your own food is right up my alley - I like to customize my food. This also gives everyone a choice and is vegan/vegetarian friendly.   All the sauces have their own unique taste and while I've never really experienced Mongolian food before, I was pleasantly surprised at the variety. I usually pile my bowl high with tofu, spinach, watercress, and a handful of other veggies, and then accompany that with a spicy sauce - so satisfying.   The recipe cards are nice if you want to try a different dish or feel intimidated by all the choices. And there are small spoons to sample the sauces before you commit to one. Starches include fried, steamed, and brown rice; udon noodles; spiral pasta; and more. Portion sizes are fair - I leave full but not stuffed. Honestly, I hate that feeling, so I am happy to find a place that let's me finish my plate without gaining 5 lbs.  I haven't tried dessert yet but I was super tempted... Will most likely order it next time.

I am a regular at this particular location and I absolutely love the food! It is a hit or miss depending on how good you make your own bowl. The first few times I tried it, it turned out tasting a little weird. By now though I know exactly what to put in it to make it taste delicious!  My only small issue is the service. The service isn't horrible but it isn't fantastic either. I don't like how they bring your drinks to your table while you are in line. I would prefer them bring the drinks when I am back at the table instead of having my drink sit there unaccompanied.

This was such a bad experience. It was freezing cold inside. They burned both of our bowls, they remade them & still burnt 1 of those. 3 out of 4 of our attempted bowls were burnt! They asked us to come back & give them another chance. I DO NOT want to pay for more burnt food! Their attempts at correcting our food was not good. Now he is expecting us to pay for more burnt food?!? I am so unhappy & will not return. I do NOT RECOMMEND Ghengis Grill on Stephanie St in Henderson, NV. Save your time & money for unburnt food elsewhere

Genghis Grill is usually one of my favorite fast food restaurants, but I was pretty disappointed with this location. Usually, much of the Genghis Grill experience comes from hand-picking your ingredients, preparing your bowl with different combinations of meats, rices/noodles, vegetables, sauces, and seasonings, then watching it all come together on a huge hibachi-esque grill. The airport location does away with all that, and ultimately you're left with unsatisfying, generic takeout-quality Asian food.  I ordered the Chicken Teriyaki bowl, which fell way short of my expectations. First off, it was way too salty and oily - there was practically a layer of oil at the bottom of the container when I was done. There was also a very skewed ratio of carrots and onions to chicken and rice, which generally just didn't make for a very appetizing or pleasant meal.  The customer service at this location is great, and the line moves quickly. I really, really can't say much that is supportive about the food quality here, though. Next time I'm in CLT, I'm positive that I won't be eating here.

Terrible food! I've been to better Mongolian grills at a mall than this place.  You get small not very clean looking metal bowls that you have to cram your food selection into while trying not to throw your back out reaching like a contortionist for those back row items. The quality of the food is poor, the cooking is random, service is hit & run. 2 of us ate halfway through our less than mediocre bowls while one of us sat waiting for their bowl to come out. I ordered mine with the "fried rice"...most disgusting brown colored steamed (not fried) rice that tasted like it sat all day long waiting for a sucker like me to order it. For a week night dinner...3 bowls and 3 drinks with tip, our bill came to $50...WTF?! I could have gone across the street to Tony Roma's if I wanted to spend that! My stomach & wallet have banned this place for me.

Ok, no one can complain about the chef here because you are it! You never have to worry about whether you can find a dish that fits your eating style that day. I love all the different combinations that are possible! My favorite is chicken, shrimp, garlic, salt, pepper & onions, zucchini, cabbage, scallions and 3G sauce. They recently added calamari and brown rice. You can add an egg to your dish. Each bowl comes with your choice of carbs: tortillas, rice, noodles, etc. It's quick and tasty. They have the ambience of a McDonald's: not a place to sit with girlfriends and gab really, but perfect for when you want a good healthy meal alternative to fast food.  They actually have a good selection of drinks, wine and beers, along with Edame and potstickers to go with them. For those who don't know what ingredients to put together, they have recipe cards you can follow and a staff that is happy to walk you through it. The Tuxedo Bomb dessert was fabulous! Whenever I approach a buffet, I try to take items off the bottom, where the temperature tends to be more ideal, so take your raw meat from the bottom of the pan if you can, so it has been kept really cold.

The food was a solid 4, very fresh & flavorful! They do not have the variety that the full Grill has, but they have 7 different combinations, all of which sounded yummy, and 2 appetizers plus beer & wine. The side carbs include brown rice & Udon noodles, so that was perfect for me. I had the Mongo Bowl: tasty Mongolian BBQ Beef & Veggies, slightly sweet & piquant. Their food score was 97, which is great for an airport food court. So why a 2? The small Asian lady in charge of the grill area which is completely open to the public spent almost the entire time yelling at the young man grilling our food. To his credit, he never raised his voice in return, but she had the customers so disturbed that after someone would place an order, they all stood at a distance. I could still hear her yelling after I took my order to the food court seating behind a short wall. It was so unprofessional, rude and just made her look totally absurd. PS: the young man in question did a great job of cooking our food, so I couldn't tell you what her issue was. I hope she's not the owner...

I'm a big fan of grillin' Mongolian style.  I love Asian food in general, so this is right up my alley.  (I must be out of the loop and super-uncool because I have absolutely no idea what this YC is that you speak of...)  I feel this place has taken a lot of mistakes of other Mongolian grills and learned from them  Here's the lowdown on the pros and cons...  Pros: **A wide selection of everything!  Meats offer the traditional steak, chicken, pork, but also options such as shrimp, crab (albeit imitation), scallops, and tofu.  Veggies have pepper and onion combos, mandarin oranges, celery, raw egg, and a few other options that I haven't seen at other establishments.  The starches are more than white rice here - they offer brown rice and udon noodles too.  **Seasonings and sauces.  They have a bunch of seasonings to put on your meat before you pile on the veggies.  I think this is a good idea.  I have no idea if my shrimp was more or less tasty because I did it, but it made me feel better having another option to make it my own.  Their sauces are all sugar based and they add them at the end (which is a plus) so they don't burn.  The how-to list of concoctions is handy, but I like to be brave and go it alone.  It's definitely a trial and error process.  **Price.  I think $8 is reasonable for a large bowl of Mongolian grill.  Granted, there are some tips and tricks to getting the most out of your dollar (pile high and push it down my friends) and some strategery to the order of which you load on your veggies.  **Happy hour.  I can't remember what all of their drink specials are, but I know there are $2 wells and they make 'em strong. Nuff said.  Cons: **The all-you-can-eat propaganda.  As a person who never makes the most of a buffet, all-you-can-eat is not really for me.  I think how it works here is that you can go back and do a second+ bowl and move up to the $12 bracket.  I like a lot of veggies and I had a hard time getting all I wanted in the bowl (yes, even with all of the tips and tricks), but I would have willingly paid the $12 to get two bowls at the get go to make one bad mamma jamma of a stir-fry.  Maybe next time I'll see if I can finagle...  **Assembly line set-up.  You can only serve from one side of the item line and let me say, it can be a little daunting.  For a first timer taking their time and getting it all worked out, you start to feel the pressure as the line builds behind you.  It's not a process in which I like to be rushed.  It's not a big deal and people can go around or whatnot, but it's not very conducive to serving a lot of people at once.  I'll definitely be back to have another go at it.  Skip YC's and go straight to Genghis Grill, or so I've been told...

I went here with some coworkers for lunch.  Some of them raved about the place and the concept and I had to experience it for myself.    You are seated first and your server takes your drink order.  She then asks if anyone is new and then takes you over to the buffet and explains everything to you.  You have a bowl that you fill with your proteins of choice, spices, veggies and sauces.  Then you take it up to the counter and order your starch and you get a number.  They cook your order on a round grill and then bring it out to you.  Pretty simple really.  The hard part is perfecting your own recipe.  There are a few recipe cards available to use as a guide. You can also check their website beforehand to get ideas.  The selections for your bowl are extensive.  For proteins you have everything from beef and chicken to calamari and pepperoni.  Pepperoni??  lol.  Must be for the kids.  Spice and sauce mixtures range from teryaki to curry and veggies consist of everything under the sun.  This is a chain restaurant that everyone should try at least once.  I need to go back and perfect my recipe.

We came to have lunch today and had an issue for the first time. Honestly, I've worked in the industry so I know it's going to happen eventually. It could have been very upsetting but for the most part I was happy with how it was handled. My husband ordered a medium build your own bowl and I ordered a large. Mine arrived first and seemed small but I thought maybe I was over thinking it. But when my husbands arrived and was WAY bigger, I knew there had been a mistake somewhere. We told our waitress, Sandy, and she went to her manager to resolve the issue. We weren't sure what was happening until she came back about five minutes later. She told us she fixed our bill and we were only charged for a small. But the problem was, we wanted a large. The price was never the issue. When we told her she sort of cut us off and said she can't do anything and she will go get her manager. The manager, kelly, came to our table and asked how we would like to resolve it all. She was very polite about it. I asked how much another small bowl would cost because I'm honestly still hungry and the small was gone at this point. She said that the bowl is on them, which was very kind. We never wanted a free meal, just a big one. I think my server misunderstood that. But I'm glad the manager fixed the experience.
Great food and service everytime we go they are very consistent ! Like this place , they closed ours here in Tucson so it was great to see they are still around .

The manager of this store is so unbelievably offensive I will never come here again. After my roommate complained that there was a hair in her food the manager came over looked at the bowl then turned to me and said "are you sure this isn't your hair?" Im sorry but are you kidding me? Even if that was supposed to be a joke that was made in extremely poor taste and offended the rest of my party sitting with me. Who ever told this guy he was funny should be slapped.

This place use to be good but now you only get one trip and have to pay upwards of 15 dollars for one bowl.  The whole point of this style of eating is to be able to experiment new creations and try maybe a couple small trips.  I am very sad they changed and as the waitress mentioned they have a lost a lot of business including ours now.  If management knows they are losing business maybe they should revert back to how this style of eating should be.  Last time I'll be there!
This place is a wonderful to practice on your architecture skills. Also, the food is great and priced well. I highly suggest this place to eat for Lunch or dinner. Pile it high!!!

This is one of our favorite places to go. There are so many choices to put in your bowl and it all taste so good. I love how they have the gluten-free rice noodles and of course they are really good, my favorite choice of noodle. My mother-in-law has all sorts of food allergies (gluten-free, dairy free, grain free) and she was able to pick choices out easy. And that is the ultimate test if you ask me.
You decide on the ingredients, they cook it. It's as simple as that. But even better, the service by an excellent staff is top notch. Our kids especially LOVED Genghis Grill.

I love this place you get a big bowl u pick your meats,veggies,and/or fruit plus seasonings and sauce give it to the grill cooks they prepare your food on this giant grill,then give it to the waiter who then brings it to your tabl,it is so good,I go all the time,love it

This is located at the airport inside the US Airways terminal. Great place if you are in the mood to consume something nourishing, and healthy. I had the vegetarian dish called the Buddha Bowl. It was pretty good, and filling. It was also very inexpensive. In today's economy, that's a good thing.

Oh how I wish it weren't so...but alas...it is. My family and I USED to love this place. We were sorely disappointed with last nights experience.  We've seen this place sink from an awesome, friendly place with great food to a dirty, disorganized place with deplorable "service". When we complained to one of the servers we recognized,  he told us that their manager walked out recently and the new one doesn't have the same standards. Well...that explains some of it. But...it doesn't explain our servers attitude or my family's food poisoning.  Yup.. that's right...everyone's sick. Do yourself a favor, go to YC's if you want Mongolian....stay clear of this mess.

This was my first time in here and probably my last! It started off with the hostess and her little attitude that she had since we asked for a better seat. Then while in line the guy behind the counter was not very helpful at all and the customers behind us were so rude and obnoxious dude dry humping his buddy! Then the guys who cook your food have an attitude of their own and got sauce on me as he "chucked" the empty bowls into whatever is back behind their area. None of this was okay at all! The food sucks here to endure all of that nonsense!

It was OK. My "Buddhist Udon Noodles" were tasty, but very salty. My wife's Special Fried Rice was salty, but not tasty. Overall better than edible, but not great by any stretch. And at $10 per, not a great value (a lot of mediocre food for a lot of money doesn't constitute a great value, y'all.).   If you're hungry, you can do worse, and unfortunately, it's hard to do better. There just aren't many good value meals at CLT. Charlotte's a pretty nice airport ... except for the food.

if you dont like it, its your fault lol. my husband and i love cokong here randomly. I usuaply mix two different chickens, one plain and one spicy. youcant go wrong with salt pepper a linch of curry and onion and an abundant amount of veggies!

This place is great...I don't know why I don't come here more often! For those that haven't been, you basically have three different bowl sizes to choose from. You can load it up with as many veggies and protein as you can. They have a lot of different options and even have recipe cards if you don't feel like making your own, but would rather just follow one of their recommendations. You have a few different starch choices and within minutes, your food is delivered to your table.   I usually get the medium bowl and it's enough for two meals for me! This place is a great deal, can be relatively healthy depending on what you put in your bowl, and very quick.   I will be back soon!

My husband and I were disappointed with my experience at this restaurant. This was first time at this establishment. After taking our drink order, the waitress disappeared. After five minutes, I had to ask another employee what to do. What I didn't know was that I had to take a table card with me, so I had to leave the counter to go back to the table to get one. We told the counter staff that this was our first time. The girl was a little helpful in telling us to fill our bowls about half full with meat and then add vegetables. What we weren't told was that there was an additional charge of $4 if we decided to go back in the line and add more meat to our bowl. There were small print sign posted; however, we were more concerned about the food choices, not looking around.   Food choices were basic: mushrooms, cabbage, mini ears of corn (cut small), onions, green onions, peas, carrots, spinach. At least 1/4 of the bins were empty. There were several choices from which to choose, and there were several sauce choices. The final choice was that of starch plus cabbage was included.  After being cooked, our food was brought to us. The flavor was ok. However, it appeared that the grill hadn't been cleaned of previous cooking because we found food in our meal that we hadn't added. They probably came from food cooked before us.

Went here for the first time and boy I wasn't disappointed! Everyone was super friendly and helpful, explained how we order and such. And the food is delicious! Got shredded beef with some veggies and the udon and it was amazing! Definitely coming back soon.

Always amazing sometimes the chicken is suspect(fatty). But I love the tortillas with scream( sour cream). I would go here more if it was closer to my house. Sign up online for a free one on your bday.

Ive always loved stir frys and enjoyed building my own. Here however everything was limited. I started with a small bowl because i didnt want to eat too much. The bowl was WAY too small to fit more than a few pieces of veggies in. When i realized i cant fit anything, i changed it to regular (which apparently requires permission from the manager). I managed to fit the rest in the regualr bowl, however i wasnt allowed to go back to the meat, so i ended up with mostly veggies.  The stir fry was mostly noodles and didnt have much mixed in due to the small portion bowls provided. Was also expensive for the amount given. The atmosphere and service were fantastic, but not the best stir fry ive had.

I had been here once as a non-Yelper and I really liked it. This time I went in with high expectations and was disappointed by the customer service and the "food display". However, I love Mongolian BBQ and really enjoyed the food I got here.  Customer Service: We were told once we sat down that they were not serving menu items that night with no explanation of what that meant. We were then asked if we wanted anything to drink without a drink menu or being told what was available. The server seemed to be in a hurry, so my wife and I both went with water. We got a very short and confusing description of how to build our bowls, again she seemed to be in a hurry. We realized once we got up that she wanted to get back to her friends a few tables down so she could sit and talk with them. I hope we didn't interrupt her conversation by wanting to have a pleasant dinner experience at her establishment.  On our way to the "food display" I noticed the bartender was scrubbing the bar floor. The middle of dinner time didn't seem like the most opportune time to clean the floors. I was glad I didn't order a drink.  The "food display" was a mess and very unappetizing. Once I saw the meats I considered asking my wife if she wanted to leave. Some meats were mislabeled or not labeled at all and some were mixed in with others. The biggest thing was the gross way they were displayed. They need to find a better way to display them. Lots of bowls of raw meat isn't very appetizing. The spices were a bit confusing. The vegetables were poorly cut and disheveled. The girl behind the counter wasn't much help either. I thought they had recipes on the wall that you could follow, if they didn't they need them. If they did, they need to bring them back.  Overall, I liked the food, but I had some issues with the way the establishment was organized and run. It seemed a bit pricey for what we got.

Buddhist bowl.  Awful, the use canned bamboo shoots and other canned ingredients.  Asked for extra spicy, instead of cooking with peppers, they give a container of hot sauce.  Manchu wok was 10x better

Delicious food.  Kids really enjoy picking all their ingredients.  Plus they have lunch pricing.  If you leave here hungry, then you didn't stack your bowl high enough.  The only limit is how well you stack your ingredients.  The Spice Trail has so many delicious spices on it.  Lots of great choices for your bowl.

I met a friend here for lunch today and was pleasantly surprised.  The restaurant was packed when we got there.  We were seated very quickly and given a little stainless steel bowl for our stir fry.    We proceeded to the bar where we added various different types of fresh meats, spices, veggies, and sauces.  We turned the bowl into the grill and they cooked it with whatever starch you request (rice, udon noodles, etc).  They were really busy for lunch so there were some lines for the grill but it wasn't bad.  The waitress bought out our stir fry once it was cooked and it we both thought it was really good.  The staff is very friendly, I will definitely be back for more.

Needed something quick. Disappointed. I got the edamame but it's under done and cold. I built a bowl and it's tasty but my broccoli is also really under done. It's like a bowl of steaming shrimp and rice, yummy pineapple and carrots and the broccoli...all but raw broccoli. In between connections and no time to ask them to make it right. Will hold me over but still a disappointment.

Interesting concept if you're looking for something different.  Personally I was overwhelmed by the ordering process.  You're seated at your table, get an ordering card (size of a box card), go pick up a recipe card, tell the server what size bowl you want, then pile up your bowl with your ingredients and sauces based on your selected recipe, and then at the end of the cafeteria style line, hand it over to the cook who grills it on a huge grill.  Food was good and portion sizes were abundant but it was too complicated between the various servers and cooks and knowing what to put in your bowl...

First time I had Ghangus Grill was in Fort Collins Colorado. Was so pleasantly surprised when I discovered there was one in Las Vegas. Staff is always friendly and remember our group (as we've become regulars)!  Food is a refreshing change from the typical dining out. Selections are always fresh, and everyone can get what they want.  Great way to grab a quick but healthy bite for lunch

I will never ever go here for dinner again!!! The staff is too rude for us?I just took the wrong glass of cocktail from my friend's side without id and didn't taste even one sip. The staff just took our cocktails directly without any explanation. He ruined my Thursday night?

Went there for the first time on a Friday night around 5 pm with my GF. I had been to YC's Mongolian Grill, which I really enjoyed but at YC's I felt like something was lacking. Don't get me wrong, YC's is good stuff, but sometimes I want to have something spicy or more savory and I feel that YC's sauces aren't very thick. I like Pei Wei because of their thick sauces, and yes, none of this food is 'authentic' Chinese food or whatever (I hate those sort of nuts). Enjoy the food for what it is.  The service was good. Nothing stellar, the server brings you water and brings you your food after you have created your delectable and dropped it off to the grill master. You are seated while your food is cooked, and this is a great thing because it takes maybe 5-10 minutes for your food to cook (if you wait it'll cause a huge fart in the line). We did the unlimited to try more stuff, and the server always took out plates and offered us another bowl if we needed. Food was always out promptly. I thought it was hilarious that the guy working on the grill hits the gong when there are a ton of bowls ready.  The buffet line was decent. I'm being a little picky here, but I think if you're going to do a buffet sort of thing, you better keep it stocked with fresh items. There were a few times I went to make a bowl and there was old chicken laying around with chicken juice just marinating the chicken. That's not very appealing. To their defense though, the other items remained stocked pretty well. The cubed beef looked very fresh and lean, not a lot of fat hanging around, just enough to taste good. Vegetables and stuff were stocked pretty well too, sauces area was kept clean and there was plenty of sauce when I went.  The cooking was mediocre. The first bowl I got was cooked well, except the noodles weren't as hot as the rest of the food, which found its way to the bottom. They managed to keep the sauces saucy and mixed it well into the food. I was turned off by the fact that the cooks were throwing tin and stuff into the corner and making a racket. Not professional at all. My GF complained that some of the food was overcooked, and while I somewhat agree, I have a higher range of acceptable cooking ranges. I'll eat rare all the way up to well done, my GF won't. I didn't get any rare, but I got some very well done, with some charring on my steak and chicken.  Great atmosphere, I could definitely go here and have a bowl while watching a game. Seems busy and the crowd is well-mannered, except for these idiot teenagers who were reaching over me in the buffet line. Don't mind them though, they're probably just idiots anyways.  Pricing is kind of an issue. Unlimited for $14 (after student discount) is something that might keep me from going back. I could potentially get just as much food from Pei Wei for less. Yes, its not going to be the same, but the two styles are very similar. If you like Pei Wei you will like this place. If you want Pei Wei, but buffet style sort of you should try this place out. You can get just a bowl for $10, but even that is a little too steep for a college student's pocket. I'd say unlimited + drinks for $12 and just a bowl with drinks for $8.50 is much more fair. I really don't even get drinks usually, but its nice to have it offered with the 'package'.   I'm really torn between giving this place a 3 or a 4. I like to reserve my 4s and 5s for places that I will go to whether I have a craving for it or not. I mean, if I'm hungry but I'm not sure where to go, I can count on a place that will always suffice and be cheap. The meat and toppings were very fresh, the fried rice and noodles option is great, but the pricing is a major issue. If the pricing goes down, I'd love to take my family there, and I'd love to rave about it. Until then, I think a 3 is sufficient.

Being a lifelong YC's patron, my interest was piqued when I saw there was another Mongolian bbq restaurant in Tempe.  To short-cut to the differences between the two, Genghis Grill:  -Has smaller bowls, so smaller portions as a result -Has more selection, with more expensive types of meat and veggies such as bay scallops, calamari, and snow peas -Is about $10 for a single bowl -Has thicker, sweeter tasting sauces that have to be mixed in after the food is cooked (Otherwise they burn due to the sugar content).  With YC's, the sauces can be directly ladled onto your bowl and are cooked with the meat and vegetables. -Offers alcoholic beverages, and has a cheap happy hour (Which I have yet to try) -Does not have any free range soup or soft serve with your meal.  Drinks are provided by your server, rather than a free range soda fountain. -Servers bring your bowl to your table, rather than waiting at the counter -Does not offer you any waxed paper to push your meat/vegetables into the bowl so you can maximize on bowl space  Since the price is the same no matter what you get, I loaded up on seafood, getting a mix of marinated fish, shrimp, scallops, and calamari.  I got some veggies, 2 spoons of spice mixture, and a mix of szechuan, Khanzu, and ginger-citrus sauce.
